clusters.title: NHS ’clearly failing’ to ensure children get measles vaccine, experts warn
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS failing to ensure children get measles vaccine

items.title: NHS ’clearly failing’ to ensure children get measles vaccine, experts warn
items.standfirst: Calls grow for reform of England’s vaccination system including delivery of jabs in pharmacies as take-up fallsChildren are at risk of measles because the NHS is “clearly failing” to ensure they get the MMR vaccine and its system needs an urgent overhaul, MPs and health experts have warned.Calls are growing for major reform of how MMR jabs are delivered as it emerged that vaccination rates in some parts of England are now on a par with those in Afghanistan and Malawi. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Fertility patients win high court battle to save embryos after consent error
clusters.neutral_headline: Fertility patients win high court battle to save embryos

items.title: Fertility patients win high court battle to save embryos after consent error
items.standfirst: Judge says people should not lose chance of parenthood ‘by the ticking of a clock’ after 10-year deadline missedMore than a dozen fertility patients have won a high court battle to save their embryos, eggs and sperm from destruction after errors meant they did not renew consent to store them within the 10-year window required by law.Ruling that the material could be kept, the judge said they should not “have the possibility of parenthood … removed by the ticking of a clock”. Continue reading...
items.content: Judge says people should not lose chance of parenthood ‘by the ticking of a clock’ after 10-year deadline missedMore than a dozen fertility patients have won a high court battle to save their embryos, eggs and sperm from destruction after errors meant they did not renew consent to store them within the 10-year window required by law.Ruling that the material could be kept, the judge said they should not “have the possibility of parenthood … removed by the ticking of a clock”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Fertility patients have won a high court battle
The court ruled that embryos could be saved
Errors led to patients not renewing consent
The judge ruled in favor of the fertility patients
The embryos can now be kept for future use

clusters.title: ‘A lot of vaccine hesitancy’: how north London council is responding to measles outbreak
clusters.neutral_headline: North London council responds to measles outbreak

items.title: ‘A lot of vaccine hesitancy’: how north London council is responding to measles outbreak
items.standfirst: Health professionals are having to find innovative ways to reach parents whose children have not had the MMR jabMore than 60 children infected in north London measles outbreakFor people living and working in Enfield, the current measles outbreak is a shock – but not a surprise. The borough has struggled with low vaccine uptake for years, fighting against vaccine hesitancy, online misinformation and health inequalities.Working closely with communities to persuade them to come forward for vaccinations is an “ongoing public health challenge”, which Enfield – like many boroughs – is grappling with, said Enfield council’s director of public health, Dudu Sher-Arami. Continue reading...

The borough has struggled with low vaccine uptake for years, fighting against vaccine hesitancy, online misinformation and health inequalities.Working closely with communities to persuade them to come forward for vaccinations is an “ongoing public health challenge”, which Enfield – like many boroughs – is grappling with, said Enfield council’s director of public health, Dudu Sher-Arami. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Single dose of potent psychedelic drug could help treat depression, trial shows
clusters.neutral_headline: Psychedelic drug may help treat depression

items.title: Single dose of potent psychedelic drug could help treat depression, trial shows
items.standfirst: Researchers find DMT – used in shamanic rituals – in tandem with psychotherapy has significant effect People with major depressive disorder can see a rapid and lasting improvement after a single dose of the psychedelic drug dimethyltryptamine (DMT) when it is combined with psychotherapy, doctors have said.A small clinical trial involving 34 people found that psychedelic-assisted therapy prompted a swift reduction in depressive symptoms that endured long after the drug had worn off, with some still feeling the benefits six months later. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: I was told my inability to conceive a second child was a ‘mystery’. In fact, I was simply ignored
clusters.neutral_headline: Women's pain is often minimized in fertility medicine

items.title: I was told my inability to conceive a second child was a ‘mystery’. In fact, I was simply ignored
items.standfirst: Women’s pain is routinely minimised, normalised, or psychologised. In fertility medicine, this dismissal is compounded by an industry structured around efficiency rather than care“The female body is such a mystery.”The fertility specialist said it lightly, almost kindly, from behind his desk. I was there because my partner and I had been trying for a second child without success. At the time, our son was two. We had conceived him naturally and relatively quickly, so after months of negative pregnancy tests I knew that something was off. Continue reading...

We had conceived him naturally and relatively quickly, so after months of negative pregnancy tests I knew that something was off. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Fertility treatment given special emphasis as Trump Rx site goes live
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Rx site offers discounts on fertility treatments

items.title: Fertility treatment given special emphasis as Trump Rx site goes live
items.standfirst: Experts say discounts on IVF procedures an attempt to fulfil campaign promise but savings only a fraction of total cost TrumpRx, the US president’s much-anticipated drug discount program, went live earlier this month with coupons available for just 43 medications, including four required for in vitro fertilization (IVF) procedures, and experts say this is probably a half-measure to fulfill Trump’s 2024 campaign promise to make IVF treatment universally accessible.“We’ve been hearing about TrumpRx for a long time,” said Dr Richard Paulson, a professor of reproductive medicine at the University of Southern California. “TrumpRx was supposed to fix all of the problems in terms of prescription drug costs and so on, and it has not done that. The only two classes of drugs that are actually cheaper on Trump RX are the GLP-1 agonists – those are the obesity medications – and fertility drugs.” Continue reading...
items.content: Experts say discounts on IVF procedures an attempt to fulfil campaign promise but savings only a fraction of total cost TrumpRx, the US president’s much-anticipated drug discount program, went live earlier this month with coupons available for just 43 medications, including four required for in vitro fertilization (IVF) procedures, and experts say this is probably a half-measure to fulfill Trump’s 2024 campaign promise to make IVF treatment universally accessible.“We’ve been hearing about TrumpRx for a long time,” said Dr Richard Paulson, a professor of reproductive medicine at the University of Southern California. “TrumpRx was supposed to fix all of the problems in terms of prescription drug costs and so on, and it has not done that. The only two classes of drugs that are actually cheaper on Trump RX are the GLP-1 agonists – those are the obesity medications – and fertility drugs.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Trump Rx site is offering discounts on fertility treatments
The discounts are an attempt to fulfill a campaign promise
The savings are only a fraction of the total cost
Experts are skeptical of the program's effectiveness
The program may not make a significant impact

items.standfirst: Exclusive: Google fails to include safety warnings when users are first presented with AI-generated medical adviceGoogle is putting people at risk of harm by downplaying safety warnings that its AI-generated medical advice may be wrong.When answering queries about sensitive topics such as health, the company says its AI Overviews, which appear above search results, prompt users to seek professional help, rather than relying solely on its summaries. “AI Overviews will inform people when it’s important to seek out expert advice or to verify the information presented,” Google has said. clusters.title: ‘It’s the most urgent public health issue’: Dr Rangan Chatterjee on screen time, mental health – and banning social media until 18
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘It’s the most urgent public health issue’: Dr Rangan Chatterjee on screen time, mental health – and banning social media until 18

items.title: ‘It’s the most urgent public health issue’: Dr Rangan Chatterjee on screen time, mental health – and banning social media until 18
items.standfirst: The hit podcaster, author and former GP says a failure to regulate big tech is ‘failing a generation of children’. He explains why he quit the NHS and why he wants a ban on screen-based homeworkA 16-year-old boy and his mum went to see their GP, Dr Rangan Chatterjee, on a busy Monday afternoon. That weekend, the boy had been at A&E after an attempt at self-harm, and in his notes the hospital doctor had recommended the teenager be prescribed antidepressants. “I thought: ‘Wait a minute, I can’t just start a 16-year-old on antidepressants,’” says Chatterjee. He wanted to understand what was going on in the boy’s life.They talked for a while, and Chatterjee asked him about his screen use, which turned out to be high. “I said: ‘I think your screen use, particularly in the evenings, might be impacting your mental wellbeing.’” Chatterjee helped the boy and his mother set up a routine where digital devices and social media went off an hour before bed, gradually extending the screen-free period over six weeks. After two months, he says the boy stopped needing to see him. A few months after that, his mother wrote Chatterjee a note to say her son had been transformed – he was engaging with his friends and trying new activities. He was, she said, like a different boy from the one who had ended up in hospital. Continue reading...
items.content: The hit podcaster, author and former GP says a failure to regulate big tech is ‘failing a generation of children’. He explains why he quit the NHS and why he wants a ban on screen-based homeworkA 16-year-old boy and his mum went to see their GP, Dr Rangan Chatterjee, on a busy Monday afternoon. That weekend, the boy had been at A&E after an attempt at self-harm, and in his notes the hospital doctor had recommended the teenager be prescribed antidepressants. “I thought: ‘Wait a minute, I can’t just start a 16-year-old on antidepressants,’” says Chatterjee. He wanted to understand what was going on in the boy’s life.They talked for a while, and Chatterjee asked him about his screen use, which turned out to be high. “I said: ‘I think your screen use, particularly in the evenings, might be impacting your mental wellbeing.’” Chatterjee helped the boy and his mother set up a routine where digital devices and social media went off an hour before bed, gradually extending the screen-free period over six weeks. After two months, he says the boy stopped needing to see him. A few months after that, his mother wrote Chatterjee a note to say her son had been transformed – he was engaging with his friends and trying new activities. He was, she said, like a different boy from the one who had ended up in hospital. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Dr Rangan Chatterjee discusses screen time
Screen time affects mental health
Dr Chatterjee recommends screen limits
Screen-free routine helps teenager
Dr Chatterjee wants social media ban

clusters.title: Intermittent fasting no better than typical weight loss diets, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Intermittent Fasting Not Better Than Diets

items.title: Intermittent fasting no better than typical weight loss diets, study finds
items.standfirst: Researchers say limited eating approaches such as 5:2 diet not a ‘miracle solution’ amid surge in their popularityIntermittent fasting is no better for shedding the pounds than conventional diets and is barely more effective than doing nothing, according to a major review of the scientific evidence.Researchers analysed data from 22 global studies and found people who are overweight or living with obesity lost as much weight by following traditional dietary advice as when they tried fasting regimes such as the 5:2 diet popularised by the late Michael Mosley. Continue reading...
items.content: Researchers say limited eating approaches such as 5:2 diet not a ‘miracle solution’ amid surge in their popularityIntermittent fasting is no better for shedding the pounds than conventional diets and is barely more effective than doing nothing, according to a major review of the scientific evidence.Researchers analysed data from 22 global studies and found people who are overweight or living with obesity lost as much weight by following traditional dietary advice as when they tried fasting regimes such as the 5:2 diet popularised by the late Michael Mosley. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Intermittent fasting studied for weight loss
Researchers analyze 22 global studies
Intermittent fasting is not a miracle
Traditional diets are just as effective
Fasting regimes have limited benefits

clusters.title: Katie’s story: her abusive ex-partner said ‘kill yourself’. When she did, police dropped domestic violence inquiry
clusters.neutral_headline: Katie’s story: her abusive ex-partner said ‘kill yourself’

items.title: Katie’s story: her abusive ex-partner said ‘kill yourself’. When she did, police dropped domestic violence inquiry
items.standfirst: After her death, police dropped a case examining Katie Madden’s former partner, despite evidence he had repeatedly told her to kill herselfRevealed: The true toll of female suicides in UK with domestic abuse at their coreHours before Katie Madden took her own life, she had a tense phone call with her former partner Jonathon Russell. Russell was on bail after allegedly assaulting Madden – he was banned from contacting her – but the conversation took place nevertheless.There was a witness to the call who gave evidence to the inquest into Madden’s death. Mason Jones, a friend of Madden’s, said Russell was “vile” and “abusive”. Although Jones said he could not remember the exact words Russell used, he said: “I recall Jon saying at least once that he was in control of the town and would end her life if she didn’t do it herself.” Continue reading...
items.content: After her death, police dropped a case examining Katie Madden’s former partner, despite evidence he had repeatedly told her to kill herselfRevealed: The true toll of female suicides in UK with domestic abuse at their coreHours before Katie Madden took her own life, she had a tense phone call with her former partner Jonathon Russell. Russell was on bail after allegedly assaulting Madden – he was banned from contacting her – but the conversation took place nevertheless.There was a witness to the call who gave evidence to the inquest into Madden’s death. Mason Jones, a friend of Madden’s, said Russell was “vile” and “abusive”. Although Jones said he could not remember the exact words Russell used, he said: “I recall Jon saying at least once that he was in control of the town and would end her life if she didn’t do it herself.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Katie Madden's death is investigated
Abusive ex-partner is examined
Domestic violence case is dropped
Evidence shows repeated abuse
Police actions are questioned

items.title: Fast-spreading measles outbreak takes hold among under-10s in north London
items.standfirst: UK Health Security Agency urges parents in Enfield to get their children vaccinated as Easter holiday travels approach‘We almost lost you in the night’ - the life-threatening rise of measlesA big measles outbreak in north-east London is affecting unvaccinated children under the age of 10, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) has confirmed.UKHSA previously reported 34 laboratory-confirmed measles cases among children who attend schools and nurseries in Enfield from 1 January to 9 February, with some requiring hospital treatment. Continue reading...

Continue reading...
